instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.820-01814: What is 820-01814? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H_RTC: What is 3V3_G3H_RTC? 3V3_G3H_RTC Is an abbreviation of PP3V3_G3H_RTC which is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Hello community!

  here I have a problem with a 15 inch MBP <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, which does not turn on.
  I checked the voltage, and it's stuck at 5v 0.02 amps for all charging ports.

  So my question is: how can I be sure it's the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip?  And which of the 4 chips is faulty ? 

There is no liquid damage, it just happened overnight.

Awaiting your reply,
best regards and thanks !

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
We need some more readings, like <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>, AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages.

Compare diode mode to ground and voltage on LDOs of all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Thanks, I will check right now.
just, what does LDO means ?

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Low Drop Output rails of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
You will undertsand looking isnide of their block schematics.

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Hello,
Here are the tension and diode mode requested:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> : 12,3V 407 ohm
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC_X</SIGNAL> : 3,3V 093 ohm
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> : 1.79V 387 ohm
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> : 3.37V 634 ohm
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> : 1.19V 524 ohm
<SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> : 0.7V 014 ohm
PPVDDCPUSRAM_AWAKE : 0.79V  090 ohm
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> : 1.79V 380 ohm
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> : 1.09V 140 ohm


LDO from <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> : 3.3V 468 ohm
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL> : 1.78V 530 ohm
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> : 1.78V OL
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> : 0V 489 ohm (1.1v if I connect the charger on the right port XA).

LDOs from <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> : 3.36V 504 ohm
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> : 1.78V 471 ohm
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> : 1.79V 480 ohm
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> : 0V 504 ohm (1.1v if I connect the charger on the right port XB).

LDOs from UB300
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO</SIGNAL> : 3.36V 470 ohm
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOA</SIGNAL> : 1.8V 528 ohm
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOD</SIGNAL> : 1.79V 482 ohm
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> : 0V 508 ohm (1.1v if I connect the charger on the right port TA).


LDOs from UB400
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL> : 3.35V 467 ohm
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOA</SIGNAL> : 1.8V 528 ohm
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOD</SIGNAL> : 1.79V 483 ohm
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> : 0V 514 ohm (1.1v if I connect the charger on the right port TB).


What do you think about it ?

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Looks more like SMC communication problem.
What shows USB-C meter if connect the battery?
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and see if tries to start, with battery connected.

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
When the battery is connected to the motherboard, the USB-C meter shows me 5.2V , 0.084 A and 0.44W.

I tried to find the <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> on the schematic, but I can't find it. Could you please explain to me what it is and what exactly I should do with it ?

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Sorry, is <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> in this case; SWK000 pads.

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: So if I understood your query correctly, you want me to inject 20V on the <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> line to see if it tries to turn on. For example on <RESISTOR>R8015</RESISTOR>. That's right ?

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
What???
I hope you didn't do that.

Use SWK000 pads, instead of power button!

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
No, I didn't do that. 
How can I use this pad if it is under the motherboard when I put it back in the case to connect the battery?
Can I use the <RESISTOR>R8015</RESISTOR> component to do this test?

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Solder a cable on <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> (any point) and test metalic chassis part...
